problem_text:
Are there only finitely many conjugacy classes of maximal periodic subgroups in a finitely generated linear group over the integers?
V. P. Platonov
answer: Not always. The extension H of the free group on free generators a, b by the automorphism φ : a → a−1, b → b is a linear group over the integers. For every n ∈ Z the element cn = φb−nabn has order 2 and CH(cn) = ⟨cn⟩. Let the dash denote an isomorphism of H onto its copy H′. As a counterexample one can take the subgroup G ⩽ H × H′ generated by the elements a, φ, a′φ′, bb′. Indeed, G contains the subgroups Tn = ⟨c0, c′n⟩, n ∈ Z, which are maximal periodic (even in H × H′). If Tn and Tm are conjugate by an element xy′ ∈ G (where x ∈ H and y′ ∈ H′), then cx0 = c0 and cyn = cm, whence x ∈ ⟨c0⟩, y ∈ bm−n⟨cm⟩. Since xy′ ∈ G, the sums of the exponents at the occurrences of b in x and y (in any expression) must coincide; hence m = n. (Yu. I. Merzlyakov, 1973.)
